The paper finds that inter-contact times between mobile devices follow a power law up to a characteristic time (~half a day) and decay exponentially beyond it, with simple mobility models replicating this behavior and human return times to favorite locations explaining the dichotomy, suggesting prior power-law-based performance analyses may be overly pessimistic, while related works explore network measurement optimization (MGRP, SLA M), vehicular WiFi (Cabernet), scalable data plane solutions (DIFANE), Ethernet backoff algorithms, multihoming benefits, satellite systems (concentrated ALOHA), ShuffleNet interconnects, GPU-accelerated routing (PacketShader), SIP overload control (Bassoon), wireless mesh scheduling, decentralized ring networks, MAC protocols (FAMA), scalable monitoring, and anomaly detection in network flows.

The XSB system is a high-performance, in-memory deductive database engine based on Prolog, enhanced with tabling for efficient query processing, improved indexing, and flexible data modeling via HiLog, outperforming other deductive database systems for many queries, while related research explores query optimization, relational representations, graph algorithms, and efficient data processing techniques in databases.

The paper classifies TCP throughput predictors into Formula-Based (FB) and History-Based (HB) methods, evaluating their accuracy and key performance factors, with FB excelling in non-saturated transfers and HB performing well with historical data but dependent on path conditions, while related works explore network coding, wireless protocols, flow control, and latency measurement in diverse networking contexts.

The paper proposes a linear incremental backoff algorithm for Ethernet, comparing it to binary exponential backoff under various traffic conditions, while related works explore wireless network scalability (MPR, GLS, ETX), energy efficiency ("wake-on-wireless"), routing optimization (power-aware, intra-domain), security (BLN, IP traceback), and performance enhancements (TCP implementation, NTP refinements, WLAN reliability).
